thread.title: French data privacy regulator rejects Google appeal
thread.title_full: French data privacy regulator rejects Google appeal

title: French data privacy regulator rejects Google appeal
text:
French data privacy regulator rejects Google appeal September 21, 2015 
France's data privacy regulator has rejected Google's appeal of an order to remove search results worldwide upon request. 
In a statement Monday, the agency known as CNIL denied that it was trying to apply French law globally, but rather to request that any companies that offer services in Europe conform to legislation. 
The latest order from CNIL came in response to the May 2014 ruling from Europe's highest court that people have the right to control what appears when their name is searched online. Google says it has received 318,269 requests for removal, and accepted delisting of about 40 percent of the URLs evaluated. 
Facebook links accounted for the most of any single website, Google said. 
CNIL said Google must comply with the order or face possible sanctions. France fines Google 100,000 euros over Street View (Update) March 21, 2011 
France's data privacy regulator said Monday it had imposed a record fine of 100,000 euros ($142,000) on Google for private information collected while compiling its panoramic Street View service. French regulator warns of Google privacy policy February 28, 2012 
Google's new privacy policy appears to violate the European Union's data protection rules, France's regulator said Tuesday, just two days before the new guidelines are set to come into force. France to sanction Google over privacy rules September 27, 2013 
France said Friday it will fine Google up to 300,000 euros ($402,180) for breaking rules on data privacy. France fines Google 150,000 euros in data privacy row January 8, 2014 
France's data protection watchdog on Wednesday fined Google 150,000 euros ($205,000)—the maximum possible—for failing to comply with its privacy guidelines for personal data. Google seeks help defining 'Right to be Forgotten' September 9, 2014
